div.p: We define two types of bipartite graphs, chordal bipartite graphs and perfect elimination bipartite graphs, and prove theorems analogous to those of Dirac and Rose for chordal graphs (rigid circuit graphs, triangulated graphs). Our results are applicable to Gaussian elimination on sparse matrices where a sequence of pivots preserving zeros is sought. Our work removes the constraint imposed by Haskins and Rose that pivots must be along the main diagonal.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: When performing Gaussian elimination on a sparse matrix, an arbitrary choice of pivots may result in filling in some zero entries with nonzeros. One may ask, when does there exist a sequence of pivots which induces no fill-in? The combinatorial notion of preservation of sparseness is important for the storage requirements in computer implementation.
Rose [9] gives a beautiful. solution to this problem for a nonsingular n X n matrix M under the restriction that I. All pivots are chosen along the main diagonal. 11. M is symmetric.

Haskins and Rose [4] treat the same problem with only restriction I, and Kleitman [S] settles some questions left open by Haskins and Rose. A discussion on the complexity of algorithms which calculate minimal and minimum fill-in in this case can be found in [6,7, l o ] . Golumbic [ 3 ] solves the problem under only restriction 11. In this paper we shall consider the general situation (without either constraint) by studying an elimination procedure on bipartite graphs.

The members of E are called edges and can be thought of as pairs of distinct vertices. We denote the set of all vertices adjacent to the vertex v by Adj(v). We repeatedly find a simplicial edge of a bipartite graph and delete it (thus also removing all edges adjacent to it). If we succeed in eliminating all edges, then the bipartite graph was perfect elimination, otherwise it was not. Clearly such a procedure can be implemented to run in polynomial time.

div.head: CHORDAL BIPARTITE GRAPHS
div.p: Inspired by the results of Dirac [l] and Rose [9], we shall define a notion of chordality for bipartite graphs and present theorems analogous to their results.

A minimal edge separator S for disjoint edges ab and cd is a minimal subset of the vertices whose removal from the graph separates ab and cd into distinct connected components. Clearly, every vertex of S is adjacent to some vertex in each of the connected components containing ab and cd.

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: Being perfect elimination bipartite does not seem to tell us much about the structure of a graph. Indeed, let G be any bipartite graph with vertices u,, u2,. . . , u,; add new vertices w l , w 2 , . . . , w, and connect ui with wi for each i = 1, . . . , n. This augmented graph is a perfect elimination bipartite graph and completely masks the structure of G. Only when the hereditary condition was added in Corollary 5 could a graph theoretic characterization be given.
